entry.title: @pe0sat This recording can be decoded with gr-satellites by shifting the signal down to baseband (not possible with the command line tool) and using the --disable_dc_block option for the satellite decoder (needed because there are long strings of zeros). pic.twitter.com/S6t9uK9E23
entry.content: @pe0sat This recording can be decoded with gr-satellites by shifting the signal down to baseband (not possible with the command line tool) and using the --disable_dc_block option for the satellite decoder (needed because there are long strings of zeros). pic.twitter.com/S6t9uK9E23

entry.title: New blog post: Connecting the Pluto SDR to an Android phone. Here I explain the steps that I've had to follow to make Ethernet over USB work (basically switch from RNDIS to ECM), and how the Linux USB gadget support is configured and can be debugged. destevez.net/2022/09/connec… pic.twitter.com/ZGqIAylt6D
entry.content: New blog post: Connecting the Pluto SDR to an Android phone. Here I explain the steps that I've had to follow to make Ethernet over USB work (basically switch from RNDIS to ECM), and how the Linux USB gadget support is configured and can be debugged. destevez.net/2022/09/connec… pic.twitter.com/ZGqIAylt6D

entry.title: @GalileoSats @tj_astro @CillianGNSS That was a suspicion, but for regular ephemerides clock and orbital radius are not "equivalent", as they act differently for users seeing the satellite at different elevations. Hence the clock should model the clock and the orbit the orbit, but it's not trivial to do accurately.
entry.content: @GalileoSats @tj_astro @CillianGNSS That was a suspicion, but for regular ephemerides clock and orbital radius are not "equivalent", as they act differently for users seeing the satellite at different elevations. Hence the clock should model the clock and the orbit the orbit, but it's not trivial to do accurately.

entry.title: @GalileoSats Are these with a single redCED set or do you keep changing the set as a new one comes in? If so, can you mark in the plot the instants where the redCED is changed?
entry.content: @GalileoSats Are these with a single redCED set or do you keep changing the set as a new one comes in? If so, can you mark in the plot the instants where the redCED is changed?

entry.title: @hennichodernich @dEnergy_dTime Was going to say that this reminds me a lot to convolving the brickwall filter in the frequency domain with a smoothing kernel, so in the time domain we get the sinc multiplied by the IFT of the smoothing kernel. I think it might be equivalent, with a suitable choice of kernel.
entry.content: @hennichodernich @dEnergy_dTime Was going to say that this reminds me a lot to convolving the brickwall filter in the frequency domain with a smoothing kernel, so in the time domain we get the sinc multiplied by the IFT of the smoothing kernel. I think it might be equivalent, with a suitable choice of kernel.

entry.title: @ka9q @GalileoSats @CillianGNSS The information bytes are reversed, and the parity check bytes are reversed. Padding is handled as usual. See this: twitter.com/ea4gpz/status/…
entry.content: @ka9q @GalileoSats @CillianGNSS The information bytes are reversed, and the parity check bytes are reversed. Padding is handled as usual. See this: twitter.com/ea4gpz/status/…

entry.title: @GalileoSats @CillianGNSS They appear when the signal quality is not good enough. Then the Viterbi decoder doesn't manage to correct all the bit errors, and some remain, so the CRC check fails.
entry.content: @GalileoSats @CillianGNSS They appear when the signal quality is not good enough. Then the Viterbi decoder doesn't manage to correct all the bit errors, and some remain, so the CRC check fails.

entry.title: @CillianGNSS @GalileoSats Hm, or maybe this doesn't make sense. I'm thinking that if we know some bytes are errorless, this is very similar to shortening the code (where you know that some bytes are 0). A shortened code doesn't give better error correction capability.
entry.content: @CillianGNSS @GalileoSats Hm, or maybe this doesn't make sense. I'm thinking that if we know some bytes are errorless, this is very similar to shortening the code (where you know that some bytes are 0). A shortened code doesn't give better error correction capability.

entry.title: @CillianGNSS @GalileoSats Error correction is interesting: since we have CRC24's, there are potentially some words that we're sure have no errors. There's no way to feed that information to a conventional RS decoder, but perhaps it's possible to modify the error locator polynomial to reflect this.
entry.content: @CillianGNSS @GalileoSats Error correction is interesting: since we have CRC24's, there are potentially some words that we're sure have no errors. There's no way to feed that information to a conventional RS decoder, but perhaps it's possible to modify the error locator polynomial to reflect this.

entry.title: @CillianGNSS @GalileoSats I also thought that the main design driver of FEC2 was to allow error correction. If erasure correction was the only goal, they would have used a bunch of Reed-Solomon (8,4) instead, greatly simplifying the decoding process.
entry.content: @CillianGNSS @GalileoSats I also thought that the main design driver of FEC2 was to allow error correction. If erasure correction was the only goal, they would have used a bunch of Reed-Solomon (8,4) instead, greatly simplifying the decoding process.

entry.title: @CillianGNSS @GalileoSats That is indeed the best I've come up with. My hope was to reduce the combinatorics, because 8 choose 4 = 70 is quite large. For GF(2^8) we can SIMD 4 + or 3 * in an int32 operation, so I can't imagine a use case that can afford that storage but needs extra fast arithmetic.
entry.content: @CillianGNSS @GalileoSats That is indeed the best I've come up with. My hope was to reduce the combinatorics, because 8 choose 4 = 70 is quite large. For GF(2^8) we can SIMD 4 + or 3 * in an int32 operation, so I can't imagine a use case that can afford that storage but needs extra fast arithmetic.

entry.title: @GalileoSats @CillianGNSS @ka9q About the post screenshot: this is for the usual I/NAV CED (words 1-4), right? It doesn't have anything to do with redCED (word 16).
entry.content: @GalileoSats @CillianGNSS @ka9q About the post screenshot: this is for the usual I/NAV CED (words 1-4), right? It doesn't have anything to do with redCED (word 16).

entry.title: @CillianGNSS @GalileoSats Unfortunately I found a problem with my idea. I'll keep it in the back of my mind in case I find how to fix it. The main driver was: take advantage of the fact that the combinatorics of possible erasures are small to try to precompute things rather than doing Gauss elimination.
entry.content: @CillianGNSS @GalileoSats Unfortunately I found a problem with my idea. I'll keep it in the back of my mind in case I find how to fix it. The main driver was: take advantage of the fact that the combinatorics of possible erasures are small to try to precompute things rather than doing Gauss elimination.

entry.title: @GalileoSats @CillianGNSS Ooops. Messed up one of the calculations. It's actually 31.3 KB of constants rather than 15.6 KB.
entry.content: @GalileoSats @CillianGNSS Ooops. Messed up one of the calculations. It's actually 31.3 KB of constants rather than 15.6 KB.

entry.title: @GalileoSats @CillianGNSS On another topic: I have an idea for a rather fast erasure decoding algorithm (only for this FEC2 use case). It needs 15.6 KB of pre-stored constants, but only does 250-300 operations per erasure. With Gauss elimination you do 350-2400 operations per erasure if I'm not mistaken.
entry.content: @GalileoSats @CillianGNSS On another topic: I have an idea for a rather fast erasure decoding algorithm (only for this FEC2 use case). It needs 15.6 KB of pre-stored constants, but only does 250-300 operations per erasure. With Gauss elimination you do 350-2400 operations per erasure if I'm not mistaken.

entry.title: @GalileoSats @CillianGNSS ... Otherwise you have 61 erased bytes, while the RS decoder can only recover up to 60 erasures (included).
entry.content: @GalileoSats @CillianGNSS ... Otherwise you have 61 erased bytes, while the RS decoder can only recover up to 60 erasures (included).
